page.title: 18Wellow Village
page.content: A{maypole on the green}at Wellow is one of only three permanent poles in Britain. At one time the pole was cut from Sherwood Forest, a few miles to the west, but the present one is made of steel and was erected in 1976. This year's celebrations were marred by drunken behaviour by just a few of the large crowd, trouble of this kind never having occurred before. Around the green are 17th and 18th century red-brick and pantiled houses and cottages, each one built in a different style.Close by is a Methodist chapel built in 1847 and the small parish church of St Swithin dating from the 12th century. A lane climbs up from the village to{Wellow Park,}the site of a circular hill-fortress, 250ft in diameter, known as{Jordan's Castle,}which is surrounded by a broad moat.
